cards.front:
Frequent reassessments of the patient with face or neck injuries are most important because:

(See Patient Assessment)
cards.back: such injuries can affect the respiratory system.

cards.front:
Facial injuries should be identified and treated as soon as possible because:

(See Patient Assessment)
cards.back: of the risk for airway problems.

cards.front:
The mastoid process is located approximately:

(See Anatomy and Physiology)
cards.back: 1 inch posterior to the external opening of the ear.

cards.front:
The upper jawbones are called the:

(See Anatomy and Physiology)
cards.back: maxillae.

cards.front:
What is the function of the sternocleidomastoid muscle?

(See Anatomy and Physiology)
cards.back: Allows movement of the head

cards.front:
Which of the following findings would be least suggestive of a head injury?

(See Emergency Medical Care for Specific Injuries)
cards.back: Briskly constricting pupils when exposed to light

cards.front:
The lower jawbone is called the:

(See Anatomy and Physiology)
cards.back: mandible.

cards.front:
The skin and underlying tissues of the face:

(See Injuries of the Face and Neck)
cards.back: have a rich blood supply and bleed profusely.

cards.front:
The Adam’s apple is:

(See Anatomy and Physiology)
cards.back: the upper part of the larynx that is formed by the thyroid cartilage.

cards.front:
The conjunctiva are kept moist by fluid produced by the:

(See Anatomy and Physiology)
cards.back: lacrimal gland.

cards.front:
The term “hyphema” is defined as:

(See Emergency Medical Care for Specific Injuries)
cards.back: blood in the anterior chamber of the eye.

cards.front:
The superficial temporal artery can be palpated:

(See Anatomy and Physiology)
cards.back: just anterior to the tragus.

cards.front:
When a light is shone into the pupil:

(See Anatomy and Physiology)
cards.back: it should become smaller in size.

cards.front:
When transporting a patient with a facial injury, it is most important to be as descriptive as possible with the hospital regarding the patient’s injuries because:

(See Patient Assessment)
cards.back: they might need to call a specialist to see the patient.

cards.front:
The white portion of the eye is called the:

(See Anatomy and Physiology)
cards.back: sclera.

cards.front:
Bleeding from soft-tissue injuries to the face is most effectively controlled with:

(See Emergency Medical Care)
cards.back: direct pressure using dry, sterile dressings.

cards.front:
The small, rounded, fleshy bulge immediately anterior to the ear canal is called the:

(See Anatomy and Physiology)
cards.back: tragus.

cards.front:
The inner surface of the eyelids and the exposed surface of the eye itself are covered by a delicate membrane called the:

(See Anatomy and Physiology)
cards.back: conjunctiva.

cards.front:
The cricoid cartilage:

(See Anatomy and Physiology)
cards.back: is the only complete circular cartilage of the trachea.

cards.front:
The eyeball itself is referred to as the:

(See Anatomy and Physiology)
cards.back: globe.
